questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true about memory and storage?
options: A. Hard disks and solid-state disks generally have the largest storage capacities.
B. Storage devices often also function as a source of input and output.
C. Most memory keeps data and instructions permanently.
D. A storage device records and/or retrieves items to and from storage media.
questions.explanation: Memory, such as RAM, is typically volatile and does not keep data permanently, whereas storage devices like hard disks store data permanently.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT recommended advice to protect your computer from malware?
options: A. Disconnect your computer from the Internet before opening email attachments.
C. Remove firewall software and hardware.
D. Scan removable media before using.
questions.explanation: Removing firewall software or hardware exposes your system to potential cyberattacks. Firewalls are essential for network security.

questions.text: A fingerprint is a small version of a larger image.
questions.explanation: A fingerprint is a biometric identifier, not an image version. It is used to authenticate users based on unique patterns.

questions.text: Dial-up access is a type of broadband digital Internet connection.
questions.explanation: Dial-up is a slower, analog connection, while broadband refers to faster digital internet connections.

questions.text: Data that a computer accepts and processes is called ______.
questions.explanation: Input refers to any data or instructions a computer receives and processes.

questions.text: Which of the following is recommended to avoid malware infections?
options: A. Some software touted as offering malware protection actually installs more malware.
B. Flash memory storage from a friend should be safe to use without scanning.
C. Malware authors typically avoid social media.
D. If a pop-up window warns you that your computer is infected with a virus, follow its instructions.
questions.explanation: Some malware can disguise itself as antivirus software, making it crucial to verify the authenticity of security software.

questions.text: The operating system serves as the interface between the user, applications, and hardware.
questions.explanation: The operating system provides a platform that manages hardware resources and enables communication between applications and the user.

questions.text: Cambria and Calibri are examples of font styles.
questions.explanation: Cambria and Calibri are examples of font families, not styles. Font styles include bold, italic, etc.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes a single sign-on account?
options: A. A security measure that allows only one failed login attempt.
B. An individual's unique identity required to access an organization's network.
C. When you enter your name into one account and you are automatically signed into other accounts and services.
D. An organization's shared login credentials for general network access.
questions.explanation: Single sign-on allows users to log in once and gain access to multiple systems without entering credentials repeatedly.

questions.text: A password ______ is a service that stores all of your account information securely.
questions.explanation: A password manager securely stores and organizes your login credentials for easy access and protection.

questions.text: A front-side bus is part of the motherboard and connects the processor to main memory.
questions.explanation: The front-side bus is a data channel that connects the CPU to the system's main memory (RAM).

questions.text: The power supply converts the wall outlet DC power into AC power.
questions.explanation: The power supply converts AC power from the outlet into DC power used by the computer's internal components.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true about QR codes?
options: A. QR codes store information in both a vertical and horizontal direction.
B. QR codes can be read with a QR bar code reader or a QR code reader app on a smartphone.
C. Most QR code reader apps show the address of the website that will be displayed.
D. If the QR code directs you to a website displaying a form, enter your personal information to ensure your safety.
questions.explanation: Never enter personal information on a website linked through a QR code unless you trust the source.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true about protecting your credit cards from scanning devices?
options: A. Security experts recommend placing each of your credit cards in separate locations, rather than stacking them.
B. Some signals have a range as far as 30 feet.
C. The radio waves do not penetrate metal or water easily.
D. The words PayPass, PayWave, and Blink are indicators that your credit card has RFID technology.
questions.explanation: Stacking credit cards does not necessarily increase risk. Using protective sleeves or wallets designed to block RFID signals is more effective.

questions.text: Hard drives and flash memory storage use direct access storage techniques.
questions.explanation: Direct access storage allows data to be retrieved directly from any location on the storage medium, unlike sequential access.

questions.text: Two types of smart cards are contact and contactless.
questions.explanation: Contact smart cards must be inserted into a reader, while contactless cards use radio frequency for transactions.

questions.text: In situations when a boot disk is required to restart a computer or device, the boot disk is referred to as ______ media.
questions.explanation: A recovery disk is used to boot and repair a system that cannot start from its primary drive.

questions.text: Two types of operating system user interfaces are graphical and ______.
questions.explanation: Operating systems may offer a graphical user interface (GUI) or a command-line interface (CLI) for user interaction.

questions.text: Routers along the Internet backbone forward data packets to their destination using the fastest available path.
questions.explanation: Routers on the Internet backbone ensure data packets take the fastest and most efficient route to their destination.

questions.text: Larger networks typically use a switch, while smaller networks use a hub.
questions.explanation: Switches are used in both small and large networks to manage traffic more efficiently than hubs.

questions.text: A(n) ______ database is a huge database used to analyze transactions.
questions.explanation: A data warehouse is a large database that stores and analyzes large volumes of transactions to support decision making.

questions.text: A(n) ______ is an item that contains data, as well as the actions that read or process the data.
questions.explanation: In object-oriented programming, an object contains data and the methods (actions) that process that data.

questions.text: A data ______ contains data about each file in the database and each field in those files.
questions.explanation: A data dictionary provides details about the structure of each file and field in a database.

questions.text: In some database programs, a data file is referred to as a(n) ______.
questions.explanation: In database systems, a table refers to a structured file consisting of rows (records) and columns (fields).

questions.text: A(n) ______ is the smallest unit of data a user accesses.
questions.explanation: A field is the smallest unit of data in a database, representing individual data elements like a name or price.

questions.text: A numeric check determines whether a number is within a specified range.
questions.explanation: A range check, not a numeric check, ensures that a number falls within a specified range.

questions.text: A consistency check tests the data in two or more associated fields to ensure that the relationship is logical and that the data is in the correct format.
questions.explanation: A consistency check ensures that data entered into related fields is logically consistent.

questions.text: In a typical file processing system, each department or area within an organization has its own set of files.
questions.explanation: In a traditional file processing system, different departments maintain separate files, often leading to data redundancy.

questions.text: When an organization uses the database approach, many programs and users share the data in the database.
questions.explanation: In a database approach, multiple programs and users can share the same data, reducing redundancy and improving efficiency.

questions.text: A back end is a program that generally has a more user-friendly interface than the DBMS.
questions.explanation: A back end typically refers to the database or server side, not the user-friendly front end interface.

questions.text: Which of the following MIS reports usually includes tables and graphs?
questions.explanation: A summary report condenses data and often includes visual elements like tables and graphs to represent information.

questions.text: Which of the following MIS reports identifies data outside of a normal condition?
questions.explanation: An exception report highlights data that falls outside of established norms or thresholds.

questions.text: A(n) ______ system captures and stores human knowledge and then imitates human reasoning and decision making.
questions.explanation: An expert system uses artificial intelligence to mimic human decision-making by capturing and applying knowledge.

questions.text: ______ information is available when the decision maker needs it.
questions.explanation: Timely information is available at the right time, enabling decision makers to act effectively.

questions.text: A(n) ______ system is a set of hardware, software, data, people, and procedures that work together.
questions.explanation: An information system integrates all these components to process and manage data effectively.

questions.text: When you use a credit card to purchase an item, you are interacting with a CMS.
questions.explanation: A CMS (Content Management System) is used for managing digital content, while credit card transactions involve financial systems.

questions.text: Most TPSs use OLTP because users need information immediately.
questions.explanation: Online Transaction Processing (OLTP) allows users to access and update information in real-time for immediate decision making.

questions.text: Information systems support daily, short-term, and long-range information requirements of users in a company.
questions.explanation: Information systems are designed to meet the information needs of users at all levels of the organization, from daily operations to long-term planning.

questions.text: To assist with sound decision making, information must have value.
questions.explanation: Valuable information is accurate, timely, relevant, and helps decision makers achieve their objectives.

questions.text: Most information gains value with time.
questions.explanation: Most information loses value over time as it becomes outdated or irrelevant to decision-making.
